study_goal: The researchers were evaluating the safety and immunogenicity of a live oral cholera vaccine (VA 1.4) administered with a buffer solution containing sodium bicarbonate and ascorbic acid.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was used as part of a buffer solution to administer the vaccine, but the study did not specifically assess its effects. The vaccine itself was found to be safe and immunogenic, with no diarrhea-related adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-60 years from Kolkata, India, a cholera-endemic region.
effective_dosage: 100 ml of a buffer solution containing sodium bicarbonate and ascorbic acid, administered twice (on day 0 and day 14).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if adding sodium bicarbonate 1.4% to mepivacaine 2% plus adrenaline reduces pain during local infiltration anesthesia for ambulatory phlebectomy compared to a standard saline-diluted solution.
results_summary: The study found that the alkalinized solution significantly reduced median pain scores (2 vs. 5 in the control group, P<.0001), with a model predicting a 3-point reduction in pain rating.
population_specificity: 100 adult patients undergoing scheduled ambulatory phlebectomy.
effective_dosage: Mepivacaine chlorhydrate 2% plus adrenaline in sodium bicarbonate 1.4%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of canagliflozin on serum electrolytes, including sodium bicarbonate, in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found small mean percent changes in serum electrolytes, including bicarbonate, with canagliflozin. Potassium elevations were infrequent but more common with canagliflozin 300 mg, particularly in patients with reduced eGFR.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus, stratified by baseline eGFR (≥60 mL/min/1.73 m² and ≥45 to <60 mL/min/1.73 m²).
interactions: Anti-hypertensive agents that interfere with potassium excretion (renin-angiotensin aldosterone system-acting agents and/or potassium-sparing diuretics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) in high-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravascular volume expansion with sodium bicarbonate solutions showed consistent positive results in preventing CI-AKI, though some high-risk patients still developed the condition.
population_specificity: High-risk patients with preexisting chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus, old age, or other risk factors for CI-AKI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic rationale, clinical effectiveness, and potential adverse effects of Sodium Bicarbonate as an adjunct to peripheral nerve block therapy.
results_summary: Sodium Bicarbonate was shown to speed the onset of mepivacaine nerve blocks but delay the onset of others, indicating variable efficacy depending on the local anesthetic used. The abstract does not provide detailed adverse effect data for Sodium Bicarbonate specifically.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing peripheral nerve blocks for regional anesthesia during or after hand or arm surgery, neck or spine surgery, and other procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary alkali treatment (using sodium bicarbonate or base-producing fruits and vegetables) could reduce kidney angiotensin II activity and preserve eGFR in stage 3 CKD patients with mild metabolic acidosis (plasma TCO2 22-24 mmol/l).
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate and base-producing fruits and vegetables increased plasma TCO2 and reduced urine angiotensinogen excretion compared to usual care. While eGFR declined in all groups, the decline was slower with alkali treatment, suggesting preservation of kidney function.
population_specificity: Patients with stage 3 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and plasma TCO2 levels of 22-24 mmol/l.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention aimed to reduce dietary acid by 50%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of sodium bicarbonate in correcting metabolic acidosis and reducing muscle protein degradation in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate supplementation can decrease muscle protein degradation by correcting metabolic acidosis in hemodialysis patients, potentially improving muscle wasting.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis (HD) patients with muscle wasting and metabolic acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and effectiveness of using sodium bicarbonate solution to facilitate the ingestion of S. Typhi for establishing a human challenge model for typhoid fever.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate solution was used to administer S. Typhi, achieving target attack rates of 55%-65% with good tolerability and minimal severe infections. The model demonstrated safety and efficacy in advancing typhoid research.
population_specificity: Healthy, typhoid-naive adult volunteers.
effective_dosage: Not specified for sodium bicarbonate (used as a vehicle for S. Typhi administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of single-dose morning versus nighttime omeprazole/sodium bicarbonate (Zegerid®) in healing severe reflux esophagitis and improving GERD symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that once-daily IR-OME (taken morning or night) effectively healed severe reflux esophagitis (88% overall healing/improvement) and improved GERD symptoms, with no significant difference between morning and nighttime dosing.
population_specificity: Adult outpatients with Los Angeles grade C or D esophagitis (mean age 58, 70% male, median BMI 29).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-volume hydration with sodium bicarbonate or normal saline reduced the incidence of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) in STEMI patients undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PPCI).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in CI-AKI incidence between sodium bicarbonate and normal saline hydration protocols. High-volume hydration was associated with higher short-term mortality, but sodium bicarbonate itself did not show a protective effect against CI-AKI or mortality.
population_specificity: 592 STEMI patients treated with PPCI across 5 Italian centers.
effective_dosage: Standard or high-dose infusions (specific amounts not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Hydration started immediately before contrast administration and continued for 12 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sodium bicarbonate air polishing powder on the surface characterization of human enamel, hybrid composite, and glass ionomer.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was found to be compatible for use on enamel, hybrid composite, and glass ionomer cements, with minimal disruption to surface integrity. SEM and profilometer data supported its efficacy in clinical applications.
population_specificity: Extracted unerupted third molars (human enamel), hybrid composite, and glass ionomer cement samples.
effective_dosage: Air polishing treatment durations of 1, 2, and 5 seconds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oral sodium bicarbonate for urine alkalinization in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: All participants achieved a urine pH of at least 7 after 10 hours and at least 8 after 20 hours, with no adverse effects or abnormal blood results reported.
population_specificity: 9 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers reviewed evidence on ambroxol's anti-biofilm properties and its potential benefits in biofilm-dependent airway infections, including its effects on sodium/bicarbonate cotransporters.
results_summary: The study suggests ambroxol improves mucociliary clearance by modulating ion channels, including sodium/bicarbonate cotransporters, and has anti-inflammatory effects, but clinical evidence remains limited.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with ventilator-associated pneumonia, cystic fibrosis patients, and potentially those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or bronchiectasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sodium Bicarbonate and other interventions effectively protect kidney function during the perioperative period.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit from Sodium Bicarbonate or other interventions in protecting kidney function during surgery, with considerable heterogeneity and methodological variability among the included trials.
population_specificity: Adults undergoing surgery, including those with pre-existing renal dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute ingestion of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) improves repetitions to failure and perceived exertion during resistance exercise in trained men.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate ingestion increased repetitions to failure in the back squat but not the bench press, with no significant change in blood lactate. Blood pH and HCO3 concentrations were higher in the NaHCO3 condition compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Eight resistance-trained men.
effective_dosage: 0.3 g·kg(-1) body mass, ingested 60 minutes before exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent advancements in air polishing, including its effects on hard and soft tissues, restorative materials, and health risks.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the limitations of traditional polishing methods and highlights air polishing as a contemporary alternative, but does not provide specific results regarding Sodium Bicarbonate's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dental hygiene practice context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether buffering 2% lidocaine with 1:100,000 epinephrine using sodium bicarbonate reduced pain during infiltration and incision/drainage procedures in patients with pulpal necrosis and acute swelling.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain reduction between buffered and nonbuffered lidocaine formulations during infiltration or incision/drainage procedures. Most patients experienced moderate-to-severe pain during the procedure regardless of the anesthetic formulation.
population_specificity: Adult patients with pulpal necrosis and associated acute swelling requiring incision and drainage.
effective_dosage: 0.18 mL of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate per anesthetic dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate ingestion could reduce exercise-related arterial oxygen desaturation (ERD) and improve exercise performance in athletes.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate reduced ERD during high-intensity constant speed tests but did not significantly improve aerobic function or endurance exercise capacity.
population_specificity: Seventy highly trained athletes with exercise-related arterial oxygen desaturation (ERD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term efficacy and safety of probiotics combined with sodium bicarbonate solution in treating Candida-associated stomatitis compared to antifungal agents alone.
results_summary: Both groups (sodium bicarbonate solution with/without probiotics) showed significant reductions in pain and hyperaemia, with the probiotic group demonstrating a significantly lower Candida spp. detection rate post-treatment. However, probiotics' impact on other oral bacteria was inconsistent.
population_specificity: 65 patients with Candida-associated stomatitis.
effective_dosage: 2% sodium bicarbonate solution gargled for 30 seconds, followed by 2% nystatin paste application, three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) prevents contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in cardiovascular patients undergoing contrast imaging.
results_summary: Most studies showed sodium bicarbonate was beneficial or equivalent to saline in preventing CIN, with some conflicting results. A meta-analysis of 19 trials concluded NaHCO3-based hydration was superior to saline-based regimens.
population_specificity: Cardiovascular patients with various degrees of renal dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) is more effective than sodium chloride (NaCl) hydration in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in high-risk diabetic patients with impaired renal function.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in CIN incidence between NaHCO₃ and NaCl groups (11.5% vs. 8.5%, p=0.76). Secondary outcomes, including oxidative stress markers, also showed no significant differences, suggesting NaHCO₃ does not offer greater protection than NaCl hydration.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with impaired renal function (serum creatinine ≥100 μmol/L) undergoing elective procedures with low-osmolar contrast media.
study_duration: Intervention effects assessed within 2 days after contrast administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the safety and feasibility of urine alkalinisation with sodium bicarbonate in patients at risk of sepsis-associated acute kidney injury (s-AKI).
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate administration led to frequent severe electrolyte abnormalities, prompting early protocol cessation. No significant differences were observed between treatment and placebo groups in sNGAL levels, acute kidney injury occurrence, or other clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), oliguria, and elevated serum neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (sNGAL ≥150 µg/L).
effective_dosage: 0.5 mmol/kg bolus followed by 0.2 mmol/kg/hour infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bicarbonate loading increases resting and exercise blood pressure and causes gastrointestinal distress.
results_summary: Bicarbonate loading did not significantly affect systolic blood pressure but modestly increased diastolic blood pressure and heart rate. It also caused substantial gastrointestinal distress, including diarrhea, bloating, thirst, and nausea.
population_specificity: Eleven endurance-trained men and women (exercise frequency: 4.6 ± 0.4 sessions/week; duration: 65 ± 6 min/session).
study_duration: Single dose, acute effects measured over one session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose oral sodium bicarbonate supplementation could slow the decline of renal function in CKD patients with metabolic acidosis compared to rescue therapy.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate supplementation targeted at higher serum bicarbonate levels (24±1 mmol/L) may help preserve renal function in CKD patients, though methodological limitations necessitate further validation. Secondary outcomes included changes in bone metabolism markers, death rates, and progression to renal replacement therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD stages 3-4) and metabolic acidosis (HCO3- <21 mmol/L).
effective_dosage: High-dose oral sodium bicarbonate (target serum HCO3- 24±1 mmol/L) vs. rescue therapy (target 20±1 mmol/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate whether adding sodium bicarbonate to local anesthetics improves their effectiveness in inflamed tissues during tooth extractions.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate increased the efficacy of local anesthesia in inflamed tissues, with clinical and statistical significance. Patients experienced reduced pain and required fewer repeated injections.
population_specificity: 200 subjects requiring extraction of maxillary teeth with periapical infections.
effective_dosage: Sodium bicarbonate as an adjunct to 2% lignocaine and 1:80,000 adrenaline (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: Single administration during extraction (duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of sodium acetate as an alternative to sodium bicarbonate in treating poisonings and to educate clinicians on its use and potential adverse effects.
results_summary: The study suggests that sodium acetate can safely replace sodium bicarbonate on an equimolar basis, though its metabolism is more complex. Future studies are needed to confirm its efficacy in poisoned patients.
population_specificity: Poisoned patients requiring treatment for acidemia or dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the role of sodium bicarbonate as an additional treatment modality in paediatric status asthmaticus (PSA).
results_summary: The abstract mentions sodium bicarbonate as one of several potential additional treatments for PSA, but no specific results or effects of sodium bicarbonate are detailed.
population_specificity: Paediatric patients with status asthmaticus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic sodium bicarbonate infusion reduces the incidence of acute kidney injury and tubular damage in patients undergoing open heart surgery.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not reduce acute kidney injury or tubular damage and was associated with a possible increase in mortality compared to the control group. More patients receiving bicarbonate developed acute kidney injury, and hospital mortality was higher in this group.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing open heart surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain levels during local anesthesia injection using lidocaine with and without sodium bicarbonate in patients undergoing bilateral carpal tunnel decompression.
results_summary: The study found that buffered lidocaine (with sodium bicarbonate) resulted in significantly lower pain VAS scores (4.6 ± 1.5) compared to nonbuffered lidocaine (6.5 ± 1.5), indicating reduced anesthetic pain. The adjusted scores further confirmed this difference (4.6 ± 1.3 vs. 6.6 ± 1.7).
population_specificity: Patients with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome undergoing open carpal tunnel decompression.
effective_dosage: Not specified (buffered vs. nonbuffered lidocaine used, but exact sodium bicarbonate concentration not detailed).
study_duration: Single administration during the surgical procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of prophylactic sodium bicarbonate infusion versus saline infusion for preventing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate was less effective than saline in reducing serum creatinine levels and preventing CIN, with higher CIN incidence in the bicarbonate group (16% vs. 5.9%). The difference was statistically significant, particularly in patients with baseline creatinine clearance <60 mL/min.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients with unselected renal function undergoing coronary procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a perioperative sodium bicarbonate infusion could prevent acute kidney injury in patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in the rate of acute kidney injury between the sodium bicarbonate and sodium chloride groups (32% vs. 42%, p=0.12), nor in 30-day mortality or other adverse outcomes. Sodium bicarbonate did not demonstrate a protective effect against acute kidney injury in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with stage 3 or higher chronic kidney disease undergoing cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass.
effective_dosage: 150 mEq/L sodium bicarbonate in 5% dextrose solution, administered intravenously starting 1 hour preoperatively and continuing for 6 hours post-cardiopulmonary bypass.
study_duration: 7 hours total (1 hour preoperatively + 6 hours postoperatively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate serum bicarbonate levels as a risk factor for renal outcomes, cardiovascular events, and mortality in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: Low serum bicarbonate levels were independently associated with kidney disease progression, particularly in participants with preserved kidney function. Higher bicarbonate levels (>24 mEq/L) were linked to an increased risk of heart failure, but no association was found with atherosclerotic events or all-cause mortality.
population_specificity: 3,939 participants with CKD stages 2-4 from the Chronic Renal Insufficiency Cohort (CRIC).
effective_dosage: Not specified (serum bicarbonate levels measured, not administered).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intravesical instillations of heparin combined with alkalized lidocaine (containing sodium bicarbonate) in relieving symptoms of interstitial cystitis.
results_summary: The therapy was effective in 60.0% of patients by the fourth instillation, 76.7% at the last instillation, and showed diminishing but significant effects up to 6 months post-treatment. No severe adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with interstitial cystitis refractory to conventional therapies, average age 63.3 years.
effective_dosage: 25 mL of 7% sodium bicarbonate, administered weekly for 12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate in preventing acute renal failure (ARF) in patients with rhabdomyolysis, comparing it to fluid therapy alone.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in ARF rates between patients receiving sodium bicarbonate and those not receiving it, with no documented urine alkalinization. It concluded that sodium bicarbonate should only be used to correct systemic acidosis, not as a primary treatment for ARF prevention.
population_specificity: Patients with rhabdomyolysis (crush syndrome) at risk of developing ARF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the dose-response relationship of Sodium Bicarbonate on serum bicarbonate levels, its side effects, and its impact on muscle strength in CKD patients with mild acidosis.
results_summary: Sodium Bicarbonate supplementation led to a dose-dependent increase in serum bicarbonate and improved lower extremity muscle strength (sit-to-stand time) but did not significantly affect handgrip strength. Higher doses were not associated with increased blood pressure or edema.
population_specificity: Adults with CKD (estimated GFR 15-45 ml/min per 1.73 m²) and mild metabolic acidosis (serum bicarbonate 20-24 mEq/L).
effective_dosage: Escalating oral doses of 0.3, 0.6, and 1.0 mEq/kg per day.
study_duration: Successive 2-week periods for each dose, totaling 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and safety of a sodium bicarbonate whitening dentifrice in removing extrinsic tooth stain and whitening teeth, and whether its effects persisted after cessation.
results_summary: The sodium bicarbonate dentifrice significantly reduced tooth shade and extrinsic stain compared to the control, with continued but smaller improvements even after switching to the control dentifrice.
population_specificity: 146 subjects with extrinsic tooth stain.
effective_dosage: Twice daily brushing with the dentifrice.
study_duration: Six weeks (Phase I) plus an additional two weeks (Phase II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of oral sodium bicarbonate in treating metabolic acidosis in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: The study suggests that oral sodium bicarbonate is an inexpensive and simple treatment option that may slow kidney disease progression, reduce protein catabolism, bone disease, and mortality, though evidence is based on limited clinical trials.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease patients with metabolic acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate hydration is superior to saline in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy in at-risk patients undergoing cardiac catheterization.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was not superior to saline in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy, with similar rates of CIN (6.1% vs. 6.0%) and no significant differences in serum creatinine or glomerular filtration rate changes between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing coronary angiography or percutaneous coronary intervention with serum creatinine > 1.2mg/dL or GFR < 50 ml/min.
effective_dosage: Hydration with sodium bicarbonate starting 1 hour before the procedure and continuing for 6 hours after.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether isotonic intravenous hydration with sodium bicarbonate prevents contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: The study found that isotonic intravenous hydration with sodium bicarbonate is effective in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy in high-risk patients. No adverse effects or safety concerns specific to sodium bicarbonate were mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease at high risk of morbidity and mortality from intravenous contrast agents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of sodium bicarbonate in treating acute metabolic acidosis, particularly in conditions like lactic acidosis and ketoacidosis.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate administration did not reduce morbidity or mortality or improve cellular function in lactic acidosis and ketoacidosis. Potential adverse effects included exacerbation of intracellular acidosis, reduced ionized Ca(2+), and hyperosmolality.
population_specificity: Patients with acute metabolic acidosis, including those with lactic acidosis and ketoacidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate-based hydration is more effective than sodium chloride in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) in patients exposed to iodinated contrast media.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate significantly reduced the rate of CI-AKI compared to sodium chloride, particularly with low-osmolar contrast media, but showed no significant difference in postprocedural death or renal replacement therapy requirements. Serum bicarbonate and potassium levels were notably affected by sodium bicarbonate infusion.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing exposure to iodinated contrast media (3,609 participants across 19 clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of high-concentration sodium bicarbonate in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in patients with renal dysfunction undergoing coronary angiography.
results_summary: High-concentration sodium bicarbonate (833 mEq/L) significantly increased urine pH, reduced CIN incidence (0% vs. 17.3%), and improved kidney function markers compared to low-concentration (160 mEq/L).
population_specificity: Patients with renal dysfunction undergoing coronary angiography with/without intervention.
effective_dosage: 833 mEq/L (high-concentration) and 160 mEq/L (low-concentration), administered at 3 mL/kg/h for 1 hour pre-contrast, then 1 mL/kg/h for 7 hours post-contrast.
study_duration: 8 hours total (1 hour pre-contrast + 7 hours post-contrast).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically examine the utility of sodium bicarbonate as an ergogenic aid for improving middle-distance (400-5,000 m) and long-distance (10,000 m to marathon) running performance.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was found to improve running performance by 1.5 ± 1.1% across 4 studies, making it one of the most effective ergogenic aids for middle-distance running. The study highlighted its effectiveness compared to placebo trials.
population_specificity: Runners, ranging from recreational to competitive, focusing on middle-distance (400-5,000 m) and long-distance (10,000 m to marathon) events.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 24-hour perioperative infusion of sodium bicarbonate could reduce the incidence of cardiac-surgery-associated acute kidney injury (CSA-AKI) in cardiac surgical patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in the incidence of AKI or the need for renal replacement therapy between the sodium bicarbonate group and the control group, despite higher postoperative diuresis in the bicarbonate group. Sodium bicarbonate did not improve postoperative renal function in the studied population.
population_specificity: Cardiac surgical patients (excluding those with end-stage chronic kidney disease, off-pump procedures, and emergency cases).
effective_dosage: 4 mmol sodium bicarbonate per kg body weight, administered as a continuous perioperative infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the variability in drug use during out-of-hospital cardiac arrest resuscitation and assess the relationship between sodium bicarbonate administration and survival outcomes.
results_summary: The study found an inverse relationship between sodium bicarbonate administration and survival to hospital discharge, indicating poorer outcomes with its use. Variability in sodium bicarbonate use across agencies was high, ranging from 0.2% to 73%.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing out-of-hospital cardiac arrest attended by Emergency Medical Services agencies in the U.S. and Canada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a bicarbonated Ringer's solution (BRS-A) containing sodium bicarbonate could effectively serve as a platelet additive solution (PAS) for clinical use.
results_summary: The study found that platelets suspended in BRS-A maintained comparable or superior in vitro properties (pH, hypotonic shock response, glucose consumption, lactate production, swirling, and CD62P/CD42b expression) to those suspended in 100% plasma over 7-day storage. The results suggest BRS-A is feasible for platelet washing and storage.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using apheresis platelets)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 5% sodium bicarbonate, 0.2% chlorhexidine, and saline solution on oral mucous membrane integrity in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in oral mucous membrane integrity between patients using sodium bicarbonate, chlorhexidine, or saline solution. All groups showed mild dysfunction, with saline solution group scores slightly lower but statistically insignificant.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in intensive care units.
effective_dosage: 5% sodium bicarbonate, administered three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of sodium bicarbonate for treating acute kidney injury (AKI), focusing on mortality, need for renal replacement therapy, and kidney function recovery.
results_summary: The study found no randomized controlled trials (RCTs) meeting their criteria, so no evidence was available to support or refute the use of sodium bicarbonate for AKI. The authors highlighted the need for well-conducted RCTs in this area.
population_specificity: Adults with acute kidney injury (AKI).

study_goal: The researchers compared the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of caspofungin (CAS) versus liposomal amphotericin B (L-AmB) as antifungal prophylaxis in pediatric HSCT patients, noting L-AmB's side effects requiring supplementation with sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: Patients treated with L-AmB required more oral supplementation with sodium bicarbonate due to decreased potassium levels, but the study did not directly assess sodium bicarbonate's safety or efficacy. CAS was better tolerated with fewer side effects.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
effective_dosage: Not specified for sodium bicarbonate (only mentioned as supplementation).
study_duration: Median treatment period was 23 days for L-AmB and 24 days for CAS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if buffering 2% lidocaine with epinephrine 1:100,000 using sodium bicarbonate 8.4% reduces pain perception during periocular subcutaneous anesthesia.
results_summary: Buffered lidocaine significantly reduced pain, with 65% of patients preferring it and a mean pain reduction of 51%. The effect was statistically significant (P = 0.0005). No gender differences were observed.
population_specificity: 54 patients (27 male, 27 female; mean age 68 years) undergoing bilateral periocular surgery.
effective_dosage: 2% lidocaine with epinephrine 1:100,000 buffered with sodium bicarbonate 8.4%, total volume of 1.0 ml per injected side.
study_duration: Anesthesia was injected over a 20-second count per side.

study_goal: The researchers examined historical treatment approaches for coagulopathic bleeding in traumatic hemorrhagic shock, including the use of sodium bicarbonate for acidosis.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was historically used alongside physiologic saline and whole blood to treat acidosis in hemorrhagic shock, but the abstract does not detail its specific efficacy or safety outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with traumatic hemorrhagic shock (historical context from the 1960s onward).

study_goal: To determine the effects of sodium bicarbonate (SB), alone and combined with caffeine, on 3-km cycling time-trial performance in trained cyclists.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate improved mean power output (2.6%) and reduced performance time (-1.2%) compared to placebo, with small effect sizes. Combining SB with caffeine did not yield additive benefits, but no negative effects were reported.
population_specificity: Ten well-trained cyclists (age 24.2 ± 5.4 years).
effective_dosage: 0.3 g · kg⁻¹ · BM⁻¹ of SB, ingested before each trial.
study_duration: Acute treatment (single dose before each of four trials on separate days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of sodium bicarbonate in patients with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD) and metabolic acidosis.
results_summary: Long-term sodium bicarbonate use was associated with improved kidney function (lower serum creatinine, higher GFR) and reduced dialysis initiation, but no significant effects were observed in short-term studies. No increased risk of hypertension medication escalation was noted.
population_specificity: Patients with non-dialysis-dependent CKD and metabolic acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sodium bicarbonate powder and glycine powder air polishing on titanium surfaces and bacterial recolonization on dental implants.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate increased surface roughness and crater formation on titanium disks, leading to higher bacterial contamination compared to untreated and glycine-treated groups. Glycine showed lower bacterial recolonization than sodium bicarbonate.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers wearing removable dental appliances with titanium disks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the parathyroid response to acute hypocalcemia induced by intravenous sodium bicarbonate infusion in normocalcemic patients after total thyroidectomy.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate infusion induced a significant but reduced PTH response in thyroidectomized patients compared to healthy controls, indicating diminished parathyroid secretory capacity despite normal postoperative calcium and PTH levels.
population_specificity: Normocalcemic patients who underwent total thyroidectomy for benign thyroid disease and healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of interventions, including sodium bicarbonate, for non-oliguric hyperkalaemia in preterm or very low birth weight infants during their first 72 hours of life.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results for sodium bicarbonate, as the focus was on other interventions like insulin and glucose or albuterol. No firm conclusions could be drawn due to limited data and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Preterm and/or very low birth weight neonates (birth weight < 1500 g or ≤32 weeks gestational age) with non-oliguric hyperkalaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sodium bicarbonate in dentifrice formulations on human tooth enamel, specifically its abrasion potential and whitening effectiveness compared to hydrogen peroxide and carbamide peroxide.
results_summary: The study confirmed the abrasion caused by sodium bicarbonate, as treated specimens returned to their original coloration. However, the abstract does not detail the severity of enamel lesions caused by sodium bicarbonate compared to the other whitening agents.
population_specificity: Human premolars (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers examined the evidence on urine alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate infusion in the treatment of rhabdomyolysis, particularly its potential to prevent myoglobinuric renal failure.
results_summary: The abstract discusses sodium bicarbonate's role in urine alkalinization for rhabdomyolysis treatment, suggesting it may help mitigate renal complications, but does not provide specific efficacy data. Evidence from animal models is mentioned, but human clinical outcomes are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with rhabdomyolysis (specific demographics not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding alkalinized lidocaine (containing sodium bicarbonate) to hyaluronic acid intravesical instillation improves symptom relief in patients with severe PBS/IC.
results_summary: The HA + AL group showed significant improvement by week 2, while the AL group alone showed no sustained improvement by week 24. The HA + AL and HA groups maintained improvement until the study's end.
population_specificity: 48 women with severe painful bladder syndrome/interstitial cystitis (PBS/IC) who failed oral medications.
effective_dosage: 5 ml of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate, administered weekly for 8 weeks, then monthly for 4 months.
study_duration: 8 weeks of weekly treatment, followed by 4 months of monthly treatment, with a 24-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate alone versus sodium bicarbonate combined with magnesium sulfate in treating tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning.
results_summary: The study found that adding magnesium sulfate to sodium bicarbonate treatment significantly reduced ICU stay duration (25.63 vs. 82.67 hours) and showed a trend toward lower mortality (13.9% vs. 33.3%), though the latter was not statistically significant (P=0.052).
population_specificity: Patients with TCA intoxication referred to Loghman Hakim Hospital Poison Center.

study_goal: The researchers were reporting a fatal case of amlodipine poisoning in an infant and described the resuscitation measures, including the use of sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was administered as part of resuscitation efforts, but the study did not evaluate its specific effects or outcomes, as the infant did not survive.
population_specificity: An 11-month-old infant with amlodipine and benazepril poisoning.
effective_dosage: Not specified (used as part of emergency resuscitation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for determining hydromorphone in human plasma using sodium bicarbonate for alkalization during sample preparation.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a sensitive RP-HPLC-ESI-MS method for hydromorphone quantification in plasma, with sodium bicarbonate used for alkalization. The method was applied to pharmacokinetic studies in postoperative patients, but no direct effects of sodium bicarbonate were reported.
population_specificity: Postoperative patients receiving intravenous hydromorphone hydrochloride.

study_goal: The study examined the effectiveness of various treatments, including Sodium Bicarbonate, in preserving vision in acute methanol poisoning.
results_summary: Sodium Bicarbonate was administered to four patients, but the abstract does not specify its individual efficacy or outcomes. The overall treatment response was positive, with 87.5% of cases showing visual acuity improvement.
population_specificity: Eight cases of acute methanol poisoning with visual symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of ascorbic acid versus sodium bicarbonate (placebo) on microcirculatory responses after an oral glucose load in healthy subjects.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate (as placebo) showed no effect on hyperemia or endothelial function after glucose load, while ascorbic acid prevented glucose-induced impairments. Results after placebo (sodium bicarbonate) were unvaried.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biochemical complications associated with diuretic use, including effects on electrolyte and acid-base balance, with a focus on sodium bicarbonate handling.
results_summary: The abstract notes that diuretics can influence renal handling of sodium bicarbonate, potentially leading to electrolyte and acid-base disorders, but does not provide specific findings on sodium bicarbonate's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of diuretic effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether optimal correction of uremic acidosis with sodium bicarbonate or other alkalinizing agents reduces renal and cardiovascular mortality in pre-ESRD patients.
results_summary: The abstract describes a proposed study protocol but does not report results, as the study had not yet been conducted at the time of publication.
population_specificity: 600 patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 3b and 4.
effective_dosage: Levels of bicarbonate were targeted to be kept >24 mEq/L in the treatment group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of pre- and post-procedure hydration with sodium bicarbonate versus post-procedure hydration with isotonic saline in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) in STEMI patients undergoing primary PCI.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate hydration significantly reduced CI-AKI incidence (12%) compared to late hydration (22.7%) and no hydration (27.3%). Lower hydration volumes (<960 mL) were associated with higher CI-AKI risk.
population_specificity: Patients with ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (hydration volume optimal cutoff was ≤960 mL).
study_duration: Pre- and post-procedure hydration (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of sodium bicarbonate and alkali-inducing fruits/vegetables in reducing kidney injury in patients with hypertensive nephropathy and moderately reduced eGFR.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate and fruits/vegetables both reduced kidney injury markers (urinary albumin, N-acetyl β-D-glucosaminidase, and transforming growth factor β) similarly in stage 2 patients, but no effect was observed in stage 1 patients.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertensive nephropathy at stage 1 or 2 estimated GFR.
effective_dosage: Daily oral sodium bicarbonate (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanism by which sodium bicarbonate treats hyperkalemia, specifically whether it enhances renal potassium elimination or translocates potassium into cells.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate is effective for treating hyperkalemia primarily by enhancing renal potassium elimination rather than by translocating potassium into cells.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with renal disease (context inferred from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether additional oral sodium bicarbonate (target venous bicarbonate 29 mmol/L) provided benefits compared to standard treatment (target 24 mmol/L) in pre-dialysis CKD patients.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate supplementation did not produce any significant alterations in outcomes compared to standard treatment. The study found no notable benefits or harms from the intervention.
population_specificity: Pre-dialysis patients with CKD Stages 4 and 5.
effective_dosage: Target venous bicarbonate levels of 29 mmol/L (intervention) vs. 24 mmol/L (standard).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various eye irrigation methods, including normal saline with sodium bicarbonate added, for treating ocular chemical burns.
results_summary: The study found that irrigation fluids, including normal saline with sodium bicarbonate added, yielded positive ocular outcomes in hospital settings, though tap water was more effective immediately after alkali burns.
population_specificity: Adults and children with ocular chemical burns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of various interventions, including sodium bicarbonate, for treating acute organophosphorus poisoning.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about sodium bicarbonate's effects, only listing it among the interventions reviewed.
population_specificity: Individuals with acute organophosphorus poisoning.

study_goal: The researchers examined the impact of sodium bicarbonate on prognosis in children experiencing cardiac arrest or near-drowning.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate, along with adrenaline and calcium, appears to worsen prognosis in children with severe cardiac arrest or near-drowning, particularly those with poor initial recovery indicators.
population_specificity: Children with primary out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, in-hospital cardiac arrest, or near-drowning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the incidence and outcomes of severe metabolic or mixed acidemia in critically ill patients and assess the use of sodium bicarbonate therapy in treating these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that severe metabolic or mixed acidemia had a 57% ICU mortality rate, with delayed recovery linked to higher mortality. Sodium bicarbonate use varied widely between ICUs, but its efficacy was not clearly demonstrated.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with severe acidemia (plasma pH below 7.20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the updated neonatal resuscitation guidelines, including the recommendation against using sodium bicarbonate during resuscitation.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate is not recommended for use during neonatal resuscitation, aligning with updated guidelines that prioritize other interventions. No specific benefits or effects of sodium bicarbonate were highlighted.
population_specificity: Neonates requiring resuscitation, particularly those born at 36 weeks' gestation or later with moderate to severe hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy.

study_goal: To determine if sodium bicarbonate (Ural) reduces painful voiding after flexible cystoscopy.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not significantly reduce the frequency or severity of painful voiding after flexible cystoscopy compared to placebo, with overall low pain scores reported.
population_specificity: 300 patients over 18 years old undergoing elective flexible cystoscopy, excluding those with active urinary tract infections, indwelling catheters, or requiring additional procedures.
effective_dosage: Ural powder four times a day for two days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of sodium acetate (not sodium bicarbonate) on hemodynamic parameters and its role in preventing/treating hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis in critically ill trauma patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant drops in blood pressure, faster normalization of pH and hyperchloremia in the sodium acetate group compared to controls, with favorable hemodynamic stability throughout.
population_specificity: Critically ill trauma patients in an ICU setting.
study_duration: Data collected up to 72 hours post-infusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intravenous DMSO and sodium bicarbonate (SB) solution for managing refractory pain in terminal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that intravenous infusion of DMSO and SB solution was viable, effective, and safe for reducing refractory pain in terminal cancer patients, with preliminary evidence suggesting improved quality of life over a 96-day follow-up.
population_specificity: Terminal cancer patients with poorly managed pain despite conventional treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the RenalGuard System versus sodium bicarbonate plus NAC in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) in high and very high-risk patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sodium bicarbonate plus NAC is effective in low-to-medium risk patients but remains insufficient for high and very high-risk patients, prompting investigation of the RenalGuard System as a superior alternative. The REMEDIAL II trial will evaluate this comparison further.
population_specificity: High and very high-risk patients with chronic kidney disease (estimated glomerular filtration rate ≤ 30 ml/min/1.73 m² or contrast nephropathy risk score ≥ 11) undergoing coronary/peripheral procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to emphasize the importance of rapid diagnosis and appropriate treatment, including the use of sodium bicarbonate, in patients with salicylate-induced pulmonary edema (SIPE).
results_summary: The study highlights that sodium bicarbonate is a commonly utilized therapeutic strategy for serum and urine alkalinization in SIPE, alongside hemodialysis, to improve outcomes. Misdiagnosis or delayed treatment can increase morbidity and mortality.
population_specificity: Adult patients with salicylate-induced pulmonary edema (SIPE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of equiosmolar doses of sodium bicarbonate 8.4% and sodium chloride 5% in reducing intracranial pressure (ICP) in patients with severe traumatic brain injury.
results_summary: Both sodium bicarbonate 8.4% and sodium chloride 5% effectively reduced raised ICP, with no significant difference between the two treatments. Sodium bicarbonate increased arterial pH but did not negatively impact ICP reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with severe traumatic brain injury experiencing intracranial hypertension.
effective_dosage: 85 ml of sodium bicarbonate 8.4% per episode of intracranial hypertension.
study_duration: Each infusion was administered over 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of sodium bicarbonate mouthwash versus other oral hygiene strategies on reducing microbial colonization of dental plaque and incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia in ICU patients.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate (Group B) showed a greater trend in reducing bacterial colonization compared to the control (Group A) and chlorhexidine (Group C), but no significant differences were found by Day 4. The incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia was similar in Groups B and C (5%) and lower in Group A (1%).
population_specificity: Adult ICU patients with an expected duration of mechanical ventilation >48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a sodium bicarbonate protocol in preventing acute kidney injury during low-volume iodinated contrast procedures in CKD stages 4 and 5 patients.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate prophylaxis was effective, with only 5.5% of patients developing acute kidney injury, and no significant changes in urinary NGAL or need for acute dialysis. The protocol appeared safe for this high-risk population.
population_specificity: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) stages 4 and 5 patients undergoing fistulography or angioplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Sodium Bicarbonate as a potential pharmacologic renoprotective agent for preventing acute kidney injury (AKI) after cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The abstract mentions Sodium Bicarbonate as a current focus of interest for pharmacologic renoprotection, but specific efficacy results are not detailed. The study emphasizes preventive strategies for AKI, including pharmacologic approaches.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery at risk of postoperative AKI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether the SLC4A4 gene, which encodes a sodium bicarbonate cotransporter, could be a new candidate gene for amelogenesis imperfecta.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that current causal genes explain less than half of amelogenesis imperfecta cases and proposes refocusing the search on biochemical processes, with SLC4A4 as a potential candidate. No direct results on sodium bicarbonate's effects are provided.
population_specificity: Individuals with amelogenesis imperfecta (genetic enamel defects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether raising the extracellular pH of tumors using sodium bicarbonate could inhibit metastasis and improve responsiveness to cytotoxic agents in cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that oral sodium bicarbonate raised tumor extracellular pH in rodents, which was associated with reduced metastasis and enhanced responsiveness to certain cytotoxic drugs. Clinical application of this strategy was deemed feasible.
population_specificity: Rodents (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety, efficacy, and tolerability of lukewarm saline and yoga (LWS/yoga) versus NuLytely (containing Sodium Bicarbonate) as colonoscopy preparations.
results_summary: LWS/yoga produced significantly better colon preparation scores than NuLytely, with 88.9% of LWS/yoga patients achieving excellent or optimum scores compared to 77.8% in the NuLytely group. The study concluded that LWS/yoga is effective for colonoscopy preparation.
population_specificity: 54 healthy adults aged 18-65.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Sodium Bicarbonate (NuLytely used as per manufacturer's instructions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bicarbonate supplementation (including sodium bicarbonate) improves insulin sensitivity or glucose control in non-diabetic older adults.
results_summary: Bicarbonate supplementation reduced net acid excretion but had no effect on fasting plasma glucose, serum insulin, or HOMA-IR, indicating no improvement in insulin sensitivity or glucose control.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic adults aged 50 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how urinary pH modification via sodium bicarbonate affects PEPT2-mediated reabsorption of cephalexin in healthy subjects.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate treatment resulted in significantly lower renal clearance of cephalexin compared to ammonium chloride, particularly in subjects with the PEPT2*2/*2 genotype. No differences were observed in other pharmacokinetic parameters.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy male subjects genotyped for PEPT2 polymorphic variants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (single oral dose of 1000 mg cephalexin used as probe drug).
study_duration: Single dose with a one-week washout period between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral sodium bicarbonate improves thyroid function in predialysis chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients with metabolic acidosis.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate significantly increased serum total CO(2) and improved thyroid function (free T3, total T3, free T4, and TSH) in the treatment group, while these parameters declined in the control group. The treatment also preserved glomerular filtration rate, unlike the control group.
population_specificity: Predialysis CKD patients with metabolic acidosis (serum total CO(2) ≤ 22 mM and glomerular filtration rate <35 ml/min/1.73 m(2)).
effective_dosage: Increasing dose until serum total CO(2) ≥ 24 mM (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate as part of a prophylactic regimen for organophosphorus pesticide poisoning in animal models.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate, along with other agents, was found to be effective in animal models for countering AChE inhibition, but systematic clinical trials in humans are still needed.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers compared the efficiency of sodium bicarbonate abrasion (as a negative control) to other treatments for enamel caries excavation.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate abrasion (negative control) showed no statistical differences in excavation outcomes compared to alumina and bur treatments, but performed less effectively than selective enamel powder (SEP) in certain contexts. The study did not highlight sodium bicarbonate as a superior or preferred treatment method.
population_specificity: Extracted molars with non-cavitated incipient enamel lesions (93 teeth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of an isotonic-balanced electrolyte solution with 1% glucose (BS-G1) in pediatric patients, focusing on acid-base status, electrolyte, and glucose concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that BS-G1 maintained stable sodium, bicarbonate, base excess, and lactate levels while avoiding hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia. No adverse drug reactions were reported, and the solution helped prevent perioperative acid-base imbalance and electrolyte disturbances.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged up to 4 years with ASA risk scores of I-III undergoing surgery.
effective_dosage: Mean volume infused was 20 ± 12.6 ml·kg(-1) (range 3.6-83.3 ml·kg(-1)).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the regulatory mechanisms of NaCl absorption in the nephron, including the role of nitric oxide (NO), endothelin, and ATP, and their potential impact on blood pressure and renal function.
results_summary: The study found that NO, endothelin, and ATP have complex, sometimes biphasic effects on NaCl and sodium bicarbonate absorption in different nephron segments, with disruptions in these pathways potentially contributing to increased blood pressure and renal damage, particularly in diabetes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general nephron physiology focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sodium bicarbonate in reducing contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction undergoing arterial imaging procedures.
results_summary: The study suggests that sodium bicarbonate infusion before the procedure can reduce the incidence of contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with renal dysfunction, particularly those undergoing DSA or CTA.
population_specificity: Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction, especially those with diabetes mellitus requiring arterial imaging.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of tricyclic antidepressant-like effects (e.g., wide QRS, ventricular dysrhythmias) in cyclobenzaprine overdoses versus amitriptyline overdoses, including the use of sodium bicarbonate as a treatment.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was more frequently used in amitriptyline overdoses compared to cyclobenzaprine overdoses, where no cases required it. The study did not evaluate sodium bicarbonate's direct effects or safety.
population_specificity: Patients reported to the Texas Poison Center Network with sole ingestions of cyclobenzaprine or amitriptyline.
study_duration: Retrospective review of 2 years of cases

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate particle abrasion in improving the shear bond strength of metal brackets to aged composite resin surfaces.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate particle abrasion was found to produce clinically acceptable bond strength, though it was outperformed by diamond bur and aluminium trioxide abrasion. The study concluded that sodium bicarbonate is a viable surface conditioning method for aged resin composite.
population_specificity: In vitro composite resin discs (not human subjects).
study_duration: 1 week of water storage followed by thermocycling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of Sodium Bicarbonate as an earwax removal intervention compared to other methods.
results_summary: Sodium Bicarbonate was found to be more effective than no treatment for earwax clearance and more effective when followed by nurse irrigation than self-irrigation. Adverse events were minor and limited.
population_specificity: Adults and children requiring earwax removal in primary, secondary, or other care settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether correcting metabolic acidosis with sodium bicarbonate in advanced CKD patients could slow renal function decline, reduce end-stage renal disease incidence, and improve nutritional parameters.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate correction of acidosis in advanced CKD patients was associated with a slower decline in renal function, reduced incidence of end-stage renal disease, and improved nutritional outcomes. These findings align with prior experimental evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sodium bicarbonate administration on metabolic acidosis in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and its associated adverse outcomes.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate administration improved many adverse effects of metabolic acidosis in CKD patients, such as bone disease, muscle wasting, and insulin resistance, but potential risks included volume overload, hypertension, and metastatic calcium precipitation. The study suggests maintaining serum bicarbonate within the normal range to avoid complications.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), particularly those with a GFR below 25 ml/min/1.73 m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily oral sodium bicarbonate slows the decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) in patients with hypertensive nephropathy and relatively preserved eGFR.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate slowed the rate of eGFR decline and resulted in higher eGFR after 5 years compared to placebo or sodium chloride, demonstrating its effectiveness as a kidney-protective adjunct to blood pressure control.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertensive nephropathy and reduced but relatively preserved eGFR (mean 75 ml/min), matched for age, ethnicity, albuminuria, and eGFR.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the treatment of lactic acidosis, including the use of sodium bicarbonate, to clarify its physiological impact and clinical benefits.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate and other buffers did not show consistent clinical benefit in treating lactic acidosis, and severe acidemia in this context remains poorly studied.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with lactic acidosis, including cases induced by medications like biguanides, NRTIs, linezolid, and lorazepam.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sodium bicarbonate in alkalinizing urine to manage myoglobinuria in patients with rhabdomyolysis.
results_summary: The study suggests that sodium bicarbonate is effective in alkalinizing urine to mitigate the detrimental effects of myoglobinuria in rhabdomyolysis patients, alongside forced hydration.
population_specificity: Patients with rhabdomyolysis, particularly those exhibiting myoglobinuria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether theophylline combined with sodium bicarbonate hydration reduces the incidence of contrast media-induced nephropathy (CIN) compared to sodium bicarbonate hydration alone.
results_summary: Theophylline prophylaxis combined with sodium bicarbonate significantly reduced CIN incidence (1.6% vs. 7.9%) compared to sodium bicarbonate alone, particularly in moderate and high-risk patients. Sodium bicarbonate's efficacy was not isolated, as the study focused on its combination with theophylline.
population_specificity: 280 patients at risk for contrast media-induced nephropathy, including moderate and high-risk subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy of hypertonic sodium salts, including sodium bicarbonate, in treating cardiac toxicity caused by sodium-channel blocker poisoning.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sodium bicarbonate may displace sodium-channel blockers from receptor sites, but its role is not well elucidated, with conflicting results reported in the literature.
population_specificity: Patients with sodium-channel blocker poisoning (specific demographics not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate and bioactive glass powders for dental prophylaxis, focusing on sensitivity reduction, shade change, and procedural comfort.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate increased dental sensitivity by 17% at 10-day recall when stimulated with cold air and showed modest whitening effects (1-2 shades). It was less comfortable than bioactive glass, with patients reporting 46% lower comfort during the procedure.
population_specificity: 25 patients divided into good and poor oral hygiene subgroups (n=50 total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether high-dose PPI plus amoxicillin dual therapy, potentially enhanced by sodium bicarbonate, could achieve high H. pylori eradication rates.
results_summary: The study found that the tested regimen achieved a 72.2% cure rate, suggesting it was not sufficient for >90% eradication but was comparable to empiric triple therapy. Sodium bicarbonate was proposed as a potential adjunct to improve efficacy.
population_specificity: H. pylori-infected individuals (36 patients, 5 women, 31 men, average age 58 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of sodium bicarbonate combined with half saline versus half saline alone in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in high-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in CIN incidence between the sodium bicarbonate plus half saline group (6.1%) and the half saline alone group (6.3%), indicating no additional benefit from sodium bicarbonate.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective coronary angiography with serum creatinine ≥1.5 mg/dL, uncontrolled hypertension, compensated severe heart failure, or a history of pulmonary edema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether sodium bicarbonate supplementation could slow the progression to end-stage renal disease in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sodium bicarbonate may be an inexpensive treatment to delay progression to end-stage renal disease, but it does not provide specific data on its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate is superior to sodium chloride in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) among patients with chronic renal failure undergoing catheterization and interventional procedures.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that sodium bicarbonate significantly reduced the odds of developing CIN compared to sodium chloride (OR 0.33, P=0.003), but there were no differences in death, congestive heart failure, or renal replacement therapy requirements between the groups. Significant heterogeneity and publication bias were detected.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe chronic kidney disease undergoing catheterization and interventional procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and renal safety of high-dose methotrexate (HDMTX) administration with hyper-alkalinization using sodium bicarbonate, without hyper-hydration, in osteosarcoma patients.
results_summary: Hyper-alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate maintained urinary pH above 7.5, prevented acute renal toxicity, and allowed safe outpatient HDMTX administration, with minimal creatinine toxicity and no severe nephrotoxicity. The main side effect was alkalinization-related hypokalemia.
population_specificity: Osteosarcoma patients (median age 18 years, range 15-25).
effective_dosage: Hypertonic 8.4% sodium bicarbonate infused prior to HDMTX and once daily for 3 days.
study_duration: 3 days per cycle (total of 344 cycles across 26 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prophylactic use of sodium bicarbonate could safely mitigate metabolic acidosis in renal transplant patients receiving lisinopril or other hypotensives.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate effectively maintained comparable plasma bicarbonate levels and mean arterial pressures between groups, suggesting it successfully managed metabolic acidosis without adverse effects. Its use allowed prolonged and safe administration of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.
population_specificity: 47 renal transplant patients with chronic allograft nephropathy, severe renal impairment, and ≥1 g/24 hr proteinuria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of intravenous sodium bicarbonate as an intervention for non-submersion out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest in children.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding sodium bicarbonate's effects, only mentioning it as one of the interventions reviewed.
population_specificity: Children (particularly under 18 months) experiencing non-submersion out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sodium bicarbonate in preventing acute kidney injury (AKI) during emergency procedures involving contrast media.
results_summary: The study suggests sodium bicarbonate is effective for preventing AKI in patients undergoing procedures with contrast media, particularly in severe chronic renal insufficiency cases. It is recommended under strict hemodynamic control.
population_specificity: Adult patients at risk for acute renal failure/kidney injury, particularly those undergoing major surgery, critical illness, sepsis, shock, or procedures with nephrotoxic drugs/radiocontrast media.

study_goal: The researchers examined the association between sodium bicarbonate/tromethamine use and survival outcomes in pediatric patients receiving extracorporeal cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate/tromethamine was associated with decreased survival in pediatric patients undergoing extracorporeal cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The study did not demonstrate efficacy for sodium bicarbonate in improving survival or neurologic outcomes.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (<18 years) with in-hospital cardiopulmonary arrest refractory to conventional resuscitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intravenous sodium bicarbonate in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI).
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate showed a preventive effect on CI-AKI risk, particularly in coronary procedures and patients with chronic kidney disease, but with borderline statistical significance. No effect was observed on the need for renal replacement therapy or mortality, and study quality was limited with heterogeneity and possible publication bias.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing procedures involving contrast media, particularly those with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal formulation of a gastroretentive drug delivery system (GRDDS) for Losartan, including the role of sodium bicarbonate in achieving prolonged floating and swelling properties.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate, combined with HEC and NaCMC at lower compression pressures, enabled tablets to float for over 16 hours and swell significantly. The GRDDS formulation improved Losartan's bioavailability by approximately 164% compared to immediate-release tablets.
population_specificity: Subjects with CYP2C9*1/*1 and CYP2C9*1/*3 polymorphisms (specific genetic variations affecting drug metabolism).
effective_dosage: Sodium bicarbonate at 3.33% concentration in the GRD-A formulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sodium Bicarbonate supplementation accelerates recovery from exercise and improves performance during repeated bouts of high-intensity exercise.
results_summary: The study suggests that Sodium Bicarbonate may aid recovery by restoring blood pH and bicarbonate levels, with potential additional benefits from alterations in strong ion difference and reduced cellular stress. However, the efficacy for repeated bout exercise is not fully understood.
population_specificity: Athletes competing in high-intensity exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Sodium Bicarbonate on performance in trained male cyclists.
results_summary: Sodium Bicarbonate ingestion improved performance in trained male cyclists, suggesting a beneficial effect. The study did not report adverse effects or detailed statistical outcomes.
population_specificity: Fourteen trained male cyclists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether individualized timing of sodium bicarbonate (SB) supplementation improves 200-m and 400-m freestyle swimming time-trial performance in well-trained swimmers.
results_summary: SB did not improve swimming performance compared to placebo in either the 200-m or 400-m trials but increased blood lactate levels and reduced perceived exertion post-exercise.
population_specificity: Thirteen well-trained swimmers (8 men, 5 women; mean age 22 years).
effective_dosage: 0.3 g·kg⁻¹ body mass SB in size 0 vegetarian capsules, taken with a carbohydrate-high meal (1.5 g·kg⁻¹ body mass).
study_duration: Not specified (intervention occurred over 4 separate occasions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sodium bicarbonate supplementation on physical performance, neuromuscular responses, and metabolic responses during CrossFit® exercise.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate supplementation improved the time to complete the CrossFit® benchmark Fran compared to placebo, with a statistically significant difference (291.2 ± 71.1 vs. 303.3 ± 77.8 seconds).
population_specificity: Seventeen advanced CrossFit®-trained athletes.
effective_dosage: 0.3 g/kg body mass, administered 120 minutes prior to exercise.
study_duration: Two experimental trials separated by a 7-day washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intestinal delivery of sodium bicarbonate on absorption and associated side effects in humans.
results_summary: The study assessed enteric-coated and uncoated sodium bicarbonate formulations, finding that intestinal delivery improved bicarbonate absorption and reduced gastrointestinal side effects. Pharmacokinetic analysis confirmed increased blood bicarbonate concentration.
population_specificity: Human trial participants (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
effective_dosage: Dose required to increase blood bicarbonate concentration over 5 mmol∙L (specific amount not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if plasma acidosis reduces mechanical performance in elite cyclists and whether sodium bicarbonate supplementation mitigates this effect during a supramaximal trial.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate increased plasma pH and bicarbonate levels but did not improve mechanical performance or arterial oxygen desaturation. Plasma acidosis was not linked to the decline in peak power output.
population_specificity: Elite/world-class sprint and endurance cyclists (n = 6 sprint, n = 6 endurance).
study_duration: Single intervention with measurements taken 90 minutes post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of individually timed pre-exercise sodium bicarbonate ingestion on 2 km rowing time trial performance in female athletes.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate ingestion improved rowing performance compared to placebo and familiarization trials, with statistically significant results (p = 0.001).
population_specificity: Eleven female CrossFit® athletes (mean age 29 ± 4 years, body mass 64.5 ± 7.1 kg, height 1.7 ± 0.09 m).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effects of sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO₃) through a systematic review of indexed articles.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding the effects of sodium bicarbonate.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of individualized sodium bicarbonate supplementation on alkalosis and performance in elite orienteers during a simulated sprint competition.
results_summary: Individualized sodium bicarbonate supplementation significantly increased blood bicarbonate and pH levels, improving overall performance by 6 seconds in a 3.5 km time trial, with the most notable gains in the last half of the run.
population_specificity: Twenty-one Danish male and female elite orienteers (age 25.2 ± 3.6 years).
study_duration: Not specified (two testing sessions with time trials on separate days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combined creatine and sodium bicarbonate (CSB) supplementation on soccer-specific performance in elite soccer players.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding sodium bicarbonate's effects, but the study focused on evaluating changes in performance after CSB supplementation.
population_specificity: Elite soccer players (20 well-trained individuals, age 20.70 ± 1.08 years, 8 years of soccer experience, average training 20 h/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the ergogenic effects of sodium bicarbonate supplementation on exercise performance through an umbrella review of meta-analyses.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate supplementation showed moderate to large ergogenic effects on peak anaerobic power, anaerobic capacity, endurance events (45s to 8min), muscle endurance, 2000-m rowing, and high-intensity intermittent running, with effect sizes ranging from trivial (0.09) to large (1.26). No significant effects were found for general mean power, muscle strength, or repeated-sprint ability.
population_specificity: Athletes or individuals engaged in exercise performance (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of pre-exercise alkalosis induced by sodium bicarbonate on perceived exertion and post-exercise performance in world-class cyclists.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate induced pre-exercise alkalosis and attenuated local perceived exertion after constant-power sprints. It also improved squat jump performance after all-out sprints, though it had no effect on overall repeated sprint performance.
population_specificity: World-class cyclists
